Thanks Jim, I'll make note of this info and also pass it on to my friend wh=
o owns that "skull" sword. Have you ever heard of "why" this motif was used=
 (other than sybolizing the fields of Musashi)? Would this type of motif be=
 associated with a person of any particular class or status? (This kowakiza=
shi came from a German collection that was gathered in South Africa. The fe=
llow died and his son moved to Missouri for awhile. Interesting origin!)

R=
on
STL

  From: Jim Gilbert

udy@yahoogroups.com

ct: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: more shinsa question for Jim


  Ron,
  I rememb=
er that koshirae of course, it was quite interesting and was well received.=
  The dates of the period divisions are not exact.  We use this set of term=
s for the Edo period =E6=B1=9F=E6=88=B8=E6=99=82=E4=BB=A3:

  =E5=88=9D=E6=
=9C=9F shoki, the first part of the Edo period after Momoyama
  =E5=89=8D=
=E6=9C=9F zenki, early Edo

  =E4=B8=AD=E6=9C=9F chuki, mid Edo

  =E5=BE=
=8C=E6=9C=9F koki, late Edo

  =E6=9C=AB=E6=9C=9F baki, latest Edo, Bakumat=
su.

  The start of late Edo would be around the early 1800's.

  Jim




 =
   Hi Jim - 

    Perhaps an obvious answer here, but when a kodogu workshe=
et states "late Edo," when does this begin, in the eyes of the Chicago team=
? 

    You may recall the "skull/bones and grave marker" motif koshira of =
the ko-wakizashi (of my friend) that went through on Saturday. 

    Thanks=
, 

    Ron
    STL
